entry.title: SAP Fiori Innovation Day in Dallas focused on the intersection of AI and UX
entry.content:
Thanks to the ASUG Dallas chapter for helping us reach new audiences with SAP Fiori Innovation Day Dallas. We had a dedicated track within the larger ASUG event in which participants could learn about the latest user experience innovations, build an SAP Fiori elements app in less than 90 minutes, and see some sneak previews of AI-powered functionality that we‚Äôre working on. They also asked our sponsors questions during a panel discussion and found many useful tips they could use back in the office.

In the keynote, ASUG CEO, Geoff Scott, made a compelling case that moving to the cloud is a prerequisite for innovation at speed. In his interactive session, he polled the audience to give people a sense of how they compare to their peers in terms of innovation and adoption of various technologies. Many companies were using AI in some capacity, and some rely on multiple AI tools.  It was interesting to see what use cases the attendees find most relevant.

ASUG found that automation and analytics are the top AI use cases.

In the UX Strategy and What‚Äôs New section, Ioannis and Ute talked about the continuing evolution of SAP Fiori, how SAP Fiori elements brings the Fiori design system to apps in SAP S/4HANA, and demoed the Fiori experience in SAP Cloud ERP. They showed new AI-powered capabilities in My Home, such as Recap and recommendations, and explained how AI built into the SAP Fiori elements framework powers easy filter, smart summarization, and error explanation. All of this functionality combines to make business users more productive by making it faster and easier to find the apps and data they need in their S/4HANA system.

We had a day full of learning and fun.

In the partner panel, experts from Mygo Consulting, Qubittron, Mindset Consulting, and cbs Corporate Business Solutions shared their expertise on:

  • How organizations measure the return on investment for UX and AI projects.
  • Where AI playing a role in UX and how agents fit into the picture.
  • The relative value of AI for business users and developers.
  • The top AI use cases that make sense for companies
  • Where to focus your efforts in the near term to gain benefits from AI

Thanks to Sujeeth, Sidhartha, Andy, and Bastian for your unique insights and actionable advice. I found it interesting that many of the topics that people mentioned would be useful in the future were already part of our ‚Äúone more thing‚Äù session at the end of the day.

The hands-on workshop focused on using AI to accelerate the process of building SAP Fiori apps. Participants used AI in three main ways:

  1. Gathering user requirements in a business requirement documents or via sketching
  2. Uploading the resulting document into SAP Fiori tools AI to generate an SAP Fiori elements app
  3. Making further updates and refinements to the application

We used SAP Fiori tools extensively. This is a logical choice since they are built into SAP Business Application Studio.

The final session of the day (and highest rated) was our lab preview / sneak peak at a few projects are currently in development. As with any discussion of future functionality, we made it clear that these demos might or might not turn into actual products. With this in mind, Sebastian and Katja showed:

  • Vibe coding using MCP servers. (Vibe coding was also part of the ASUG keynote, so this is clearly becoming a mainstream topic, at least among software developers.)
  • App Finder to make it easier to find information in your S/4HANA system.
  • Easy Fill, which speeds up data entry by extracting content from an email or other text and using it to update the relevant fields in an app built using an SAP Fiori elements object page.
  • Smart Helpers to make it easier to get your work done in SAP. I‚Äôm being deliberately vague here as we‚Äôll share more at SAP TechEd and its companion roadshows in early November 2025.

Thanks to everyone who made SAP Fiori Innovation Day a success

SAP Presenters (in order of appearance): Ioannis Grammatikakis, Ute Oemler, Sebastian Steinhauer, Katja Zoch

SAP Fiori Innovation Day sponsors: cbs Corporate Business Solutions, Mindset Consulting, Qubittron, and Mygo Consulting

ASUG events team: Nicole Kern, Kara Hughes

ASUG volunteers: Heather Davis, Simon To

Behind the scenes team: all the developers, architects, product managers and other colleagues who built the functionality and set up the demos and hands-on systems.

All the customers: we appreciate your questions, which help us understand your priorities and focus our development resources.

Next steps

  • Register for the monthly SAP Fiori development roundtable call to meet other developers and architects who build SAP Fiori apps.
  • Subscribe to the SAP Fiori development newsletter, in which we share updates on SAP Fiori elements, SAP Fiori tools, SAPUI5, and SAP Build Code every other month.
  • Explore the SAP Fiori Development Portal to see how SAP Fiori elements can boost developer productivity, drive UX consistency, and ensure your apps have the enterprise readiness features your users expect.
  • Join us at TechEd Berlin or virtual or at the next SAP Fiori Innovation Day in Walldorf

entry.title: Career Advice: Choosing Between SAP Ariba, EWM, and PP
entry.content:
Hello, 

I‚Äôm an Industrial Engineer with no prior work experience, but I speak four languages ‚Äî English, German, Turkish, and Arabic. I‚Äôve recently completed hands-on training in SAP MM and am now planning to learn another SAP module to strengthen my career path.

My goal is to build a strong professional profile and find good job opportunities in the Gulf region, where SAP is in high demand. I want to choose a module that aligns with my industrial engineering background, complements my SAP MM knowledge, leverages my language skills, and offers long-term career stability ‚Äî even with the growing impact of AI and automation.

Currently, I‚Äôm considering 1) SAP Ariba(e.g., Procurement, Supplier Management, Sourcing ..) and 2) SAP EWM. I am also thinking about SAP PP, but I believe its opportunities are limited, as it is mostly confined to the industrial sector. Additionally, I would like advice on whether to focus on Cloud Private Edition or On-Premise for SAP MM and the next module.

Which module and deployment type would you recommend to help me stay competitive and future-proof my career in the Gulf market?

Thank you very much for your advice!

entry.title: Local annotations example for SAPUI5 smart control
entry.content:
Hi All,

while developing the custom free-style UI5 app with OData v2, I‚Äôm using SAP smart controls to save some development time, and I have some examples to share.

PresentationVariant Annotation

  • Defines the visualizations and sort order for the UI presentation.
  • Visualizations are defined using UI.LineItem annotation.
  • Sort order is based on the given field property in descending order.
  • Note: under my experience, if you use ResponsiveTable type, then the sorter can not be applied by annotation.
<Annotations Target="your_srv.entity_type">
  <Annotation Term="com.sap.vocabularies.UI.v1.PresentationVariant">
    <Record>
      <PropertyValue Property="Visualizations">
        <Collection>
          <AnnotationPath>@UI.LineItem</AnnotationPath>
        </Collection>
      </PropertyValue>
      <PropertyValue Property="SortOrder">
        <Collection>
          <Record Type="Common.SortOrderType">
            <PropertyValue Property="Property" PropertyPath="field1" />
            <PropertyValue Property="Descending" Bool="true"/>
          </Record>
        </Collection>
        <Collection>
          <Record Type="Common.SortOrderType">
            <PropertyValue Property="Property" PropertyPath="field2" />
            <PropertyValue Property="Descending" Bool="true"/>
          </Record>
        </Collection>
      </PropertyValue>
    </Record>
  </Annotation>
</Annotations>

 

FilterRestrictions Annotation:

  • Specifies the filter restrictions for the entity type.
  • Requires filters to be applied and lists properties with filter expression restrictions.
  • In this example, both field1 and field2 are set as mandatory filters, and only a single value is allowed.
<Annotations Target="your_srv.your_srv_Entities/EntitySet">
  <Annotation Term="Org.OData.Capabilities.V1.FilterRestrictions">
    <Record Type="Capabilities.FilterRestrictionsType">
      <PropertyValue Property="RequiresFilter" Bool="true"/>
      <PropertyValue Property="RequiredProperties">
        <Collection>
          <PropertyPath>field1</PropertyPath>
          <PropertyPath>field2</PropertyPath>
        </Collection>
      </PropertyValue>
      <PropertyValue Property="FilterExpressionRestrictions">
        <Collection>
          <Record Type="Capabilities.FilterExpressionRestrictionType">
            <PropertyValue Property="Property" PropertyPath="field1"/>
            <PropertyValue Property="AllowedExpressions" String="SingleValue"/>
          </Record>
          <Record Type="Capabilities.FilterExpressionRestrictionType">
            <PropertyValue Property="Property" PropertyPath="field2"/>
            <PropertyValue Property="AllowedExpressions" String="SingleValue"/>
          </Record>
        </Collection>
      </PropertyValue>
    </Record>
  </Annotation>
</Annotations>

RequiresFilter to set mandatory

Single Value only in value help

 

Common.FieldControl:

  • Hides certain fields or properties based on field control type.
  • Used to hide fields like field1.
<Annotations Target="your_srv.EntityType/field1">
  <Annotation Term="com.sap.vocabularies.Common.v1.FieldControl" EnumMember="com.sap.vocabularies.Common.v1.FieldControlType/Hidden"/>
</Annotations>

You can also use this annotation to field binded Value List.

 

Common.Text and UI.TextArrangement Annotations:

  • Specifies the text arrangement.
  • Defines whether text should be displayed first, last, or only.
  • Example see below value list annotation.
<Annotations Target="your_srv.EntityType/field1">
  <Annotation Term="Common.Text" Path="field1_name">
    <Annotation Term="UI.TextArrangement" EnumMember="UI.TextArrangementType/TextFirst"/></Annotation>
  <Annotation Term="Common.ValueList">
    <Record>
      <PropertyValue Property="Label" String="{i18n>Field1}"/>
      <PropertyValue Property="CollectionPath" String="ZEXAMPLE_VH"/>
      <PropertyValue Bool="true" Property="SearchSupported"/>
      <PropertyValue Property="Parameters">
        <Collection>
          <Record Type="Common.ValueListParameterOut">
            <PropertyValue Property="LocalDataProperty" PropertyPath="field1"/>
            <PropertyValue Property="ValueListProperty" String="ValueList_field1"/>
          </Record>
          <Record Type="Common.ValueListParameterDisplayOnly">
            <PropertyValue Property="ValueListProperty" String="ValueList_field1_name" />
          </Record>
        </Collection>
      </PropertyValue>
    </Record>
  </Annotation>
</Annotations>

 

 UI.HiddenFilter Annotation:

  • Hides certain filters in the mentioned entity in Target attribute.
  • this can be implemented in both your data entity (hide in smartFilters) or value help entity(hide in value help dialog).
<Annotations Target="your_srv.EntityType/field1">
  <Annotation Term="UI.HiddenFilter" Bool="true"/>
</Annotations>

 

You can also find some local annotation examples in this blog by Chandra: https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-members/some-of-ui-annotations-local-annotations-for-lrop-fiori-application/ba-p/13526816 

I hope my examples are clear and can save some of your development time.

 

Thanks,

Daniel

entry.title: Re: Career Advice: Choosing Between SAP Ariba, EWM, and PP
entry.content:
You need to get hands-on experience.

Collecting "modules" like some kind of badges will not get you anywhere in SAP world. It's not the game where whoever has more "modules" wins. (In fact, it's sometimes the exact opposite.) Anyone can take a course or pass a test. The real, practical experience is what is valued most. Focus on that first.

entry.title: IAM Apps tab missing in Maintain Business Roles app after transport to QAS (S/4HANA Cloud Public Edi
entry.content:
Hi Experts,

We are currently using SAP S/4HANA Cloud, Public Edition and have two tenants: DEV and QAS.

On the DEV system, we created a custom Business Role via the Maintain Business Roles app.
The role includes IAM-related catalogs, and everything displays correctly ‚Äî especially the IAM Apps tab within the role details screen.

However, after transporting the same role to the QAS system, the IAM Apps tab is completely missing from the Maintain Business Roles UI.
Other tabs (like Business Catalogs, Restrictions, etc.) appear as usual.

I‚Äôve confirmed that:

  • The business catalog assignments are identical in both systems.

  • My user has SAP_BR_ADMINISTRATOR and other required authorizations.

  • The role object was transported successfully without error.

Has anyone experienced this behavior before?
Is there a specific configuration or authorization required to make the IAM Apps tab visible in QAS as well?

Any advice or SAP Note reference would be appreciated üôè

Thanks in advance

entry.title: Error stop occurred during SAP package import (tcode: SPAM) at AUTO_MOD_SPAU phase.
entry.content:
An error stop occurred during the package import process in SAP (transaction code: SPAM) at the AUTO_MOD_SPAU phase.

 

- Env.

SPAM 7.40/0081

 

- Target Components and Versions

SAP_BASIS: SAPKB74029 ‚Üí SAPKB74030

SAP_GWFND: SAPK-74029INSAPGWFND ‚Üí SAPK-74030INSAPGWFND

 

SPAM status: Error stop

Import Phase: AUTO_MOD_SPAU

 

During the import process to version 74030, a Runtime Error: DBSQL_INTERNAL_ERROR occurred.

I retried the import using the ‚ÄúIgnore General Error‚Äù option, but it stopped again at the same point.

 

The displayed message is as follows:

The termination occurred in the ABAP program "SAPRUPGM", in the routine "SELECT_DELETED_OBJECTS".
The main program was "SAPRUPRM".

entry.title: GRC Tuesdays: What‚Äôs New in SAP solutions for Three Lines, Q3 2025 to Q4 2025
entry.content:
It‚Äôs the end of what has been a busy year for SAP‚Äôs GRC Product Management and Development teams. And I am sure wouldn‚Äôt have missed that a lot of the focus has gone into the preparation of the SAP GRC for SAP HANA 1.0 (SAP GRC 2026) version.

But the teams have also worked diligently on continuously providing enhancements to the existing solutions so that you don‚Äôt have to wait to benefit from multiple innovations.

In this blog, I have selected a few recently delivered capabilities in SAP solutions for Three Lines of Defense available through the latest Support Packages (SP26 and SP27) that I thought would be of interest. But I have also listed at this bottom of this blog the direct links to the dedicated sections of the Help Portal where you will not only find much more detailed information but also many other enhancements that I haven‚Äôt included below. So, feel free to have a look and browse further!

 

Focus on SAP Process Control for Internal Control and Compliance

 

Monitoring CCM adequacy

 

For the reporting Monitoring Business Rules and Connectors, users can now compare control frequency and job frequency:

o   Control with no frequency shows red icon

o   Control with no job shows red icon

o   Control or job with customized frequency shows yellow icon

o   Control frequency higher than job frequency shows yellow icon

o   Control frequency equalling to job frequency shows green icon

o   Control frequency lower than job frequency shows green icon

Control with no frequency

Control with no Jobs

Control with recurring frequency

Control with customized frequency

 

 

Removal of the 100-character limit for attachment

 

Previously, when adding a file to Attachments and Links via option "Add Files" there was a technical limit of 100 characters on the filename length. This limitation on the filename length has been removed.

 

Focus on SAP Risk Management for Enterprise and Operational Risk Management

 

Response Grouping

 

It's now possible to group multiple responses together for a single risk and define how their mitigation values should be taken over for the analysis calculation. To achieve this, users can mark multiple responses and put them into a group and define what logic should be used to calculate the mitigation values. Risk analysis calculation automatically considers this grouping accordingly.

The aggregation of the grouped responses includes:

o   Maximum mitigation value from the grouped responses

o   Minimum mitigation value from the grouped responses

o   Average mitigation value from the grouped responses

 

 

 

 

Business Impact Analysis (BIA) monitoring

 

 

Following the introduction of the Business Impact Analysis capability in SAP Risk Management last year (cf. prior GRC Tuesdays blog), 2 new reports have been added to help users monitor business impact analysis:

o   Business Impact Analysis

o   BIA Survey Results

These can be accessed in the ‚ÄúRisks and Opportunities‚Äù section of the ‚ÄúReports and Analytics‚Äù work center.

 

Focus on SAP Audit Management for Independent Assurance

 

Rolling and non-rolling audit plans

 

When creating a new audit plan, auditors can now select from the two audit plan types: ‚ÄúRolling‚Äù and ‚ÄúNon-rolling‚Äù. A rolling audit plan allows users to create a successor audit plan by copying the original audit plan. The successor plan, or the new audit plan, carries forward the risks, auditable items, and unfinished audits from the original audit plan. Auditors can adjust the goals, scope, and timeline of the new audit plan and continue the unfinished audits.

 

A non-rolling audit plan is a standalone plan that does not automatically carry forward risks, auditable items, or unfinished audits to any future audit plans. Each non-rolling audit plan is treated as an independent cycle, with its own defined scope, objectives, and timeline. At the conclusion of the plan, any uncompleted audits or outstanding items are not propagated to subsequent plans unless manually re-added by the auditor. This type is typically used for one-time audits, project-specific reviews, or when a clean break from prior planning cycles is desired.

 

 

 

 

Risk Matrix

 

 

Users can now maintain a risk matrix for risk analysis. With a risk matrix, the risk level is automatically determined based on the likelihood and impact. Given a likelihood level and impact level, the risk level is automatically determined against the risk matrix.

 

Referencing action plans

 

If a finding can be resolved by the action plans of other findings in the same audit, auditors can create references to those action plans, instead of re-creating the same action plans again.

 

 

Looking for more information?

 

Since I am sure this short blog won‚Äôt have answered all your questions ‚Äì and because it didn‚Äôt list all the enhancements delivered but just a selection, I would also recommend having a look at the links below:

  • What‚Äôs New in SAP Process Control
  • What‚Äôs New in SAP Risk Management
  • What‚Äôs New in SAP Audit Management

Finally, in case you still want to hear more about it, we‚Äôll have a dedicated session during next year‚Äôs SAP for Internal Controls, Compliance and Risk Management Conference in March 2026 in Amsterdam. Join us on site to learn more!

I look forward to reading your thoughts and comments on this blog.

And if you are interested in learning more about SAP solutions for Governance, Risk, and Compliance, feel free to fill-in the demo request form!

entry.title: Urgent: Unable to Access SAP Process Automation Project ‚Äì Deployment and Performance Issues
entry.content:
Hello everyone,

I‚Äôm currently experiencing a serious issue with SAP Process Automation, and I would really appreciate any advice or help from the community.

Here‚Äôs what happened:

Yesterday, I tried to deploy a new version of my automation project. Out of around more than 10 deployment attempts, only 1 was successful.
When it finally deployed, the process execution became extremely slow ‚Äî it took about 40‚Äì50 minutes to complete (normally it only takes around 30‚Äì40 seconds).
Today, I cannot access my SAP Process Automation project at all. The system seems completely unavailable for me.

Additional information:
Everything was working perfectly just a few days ago.
I didn‚Äôt make any configuration or environment changes.

Has anyone else encountered similar issues recently?
Or does anyone know if there‚Äôs an ongoing incident affecting SAP Process Automation services?

Any guidance or suggestions would be greatly appreciated.

Thank you so much in advance! 

SAP Workflow Management, process visibility capability  
SAP Build Process Automation  

SAP BTP ABAP environment  

SAP Workflow Management

entry.title: Re: Accruals & Deductions for Casual/Hourly Workers

impex.import.workers=#cores * 2

Property

entry.title: Re: Import Tab in Purchase Order for Intercompany Stock T...
entry.content:
Check the below workarounds

Go to OMGT, Set the flag to always display the import tab, regardless of country logic. But please note, import tab will appear even for domestic STOs (e.g., DE ‚Üí DE), which may confuse users or require additional training.

Create a dummy plant in the Netherlands under the same company code. Assign the Dutch storage location to this dummy plant. SAP will then recognize the STO as cross-border (NL ‚Üí DE). Here one advantage is it aligns with SAP‚Äôs standard logic, but on the other side, it adds complexity to master data and may affect valuation or reporting.

For any reasons, if both the above options are not acceptable to client, then, try with BAdI ME_PROCESS_PO_CUST or user exit EXIT_SAPMM06E_013 to override the import tab logic.

You can write custom logic to:

  • Check the address country of the issuing storage location.
  • Compare it with the receiving plant‚Äôs country.
  • Force the import tab to appear if they differ.

entry.title: Re: Access Restriction based on maintenance order type
entry.content:
Ok in that case, you can still restrict with order types and Business transactions which should be available in this object. Create separate roles for each transaction:

  • Role A: Includes IW31, IW32, IW33 for PM01 (corrective).
  • Role B: Includes only IW33 for PM02 (preventive).

Use transaction codes and order type restrictions in combination. This way, supervisors can only create/change PM01 orders and only display PM02 orders.

entry.title: Re: ChaRM 4 system landscape not importing to Pre-Prod
entry.content:
Hi,

it works as designed. The main idea is that after having set the status TestedOK, the system releases (after a security check tracking not tested changes) the original transport, which is now waiting in the import queue of the QA system for the cycle import (often scheduled at high frequency).

IF you need a preliminary import, obviously, this import has to be triggered from the online, because only thus the kernel program tp will create an import selection into the PreProd. Only when the preliminary step is approved, it is safe to execute this import.

Now, in a 4 system landscape you have to put somewhere the online import into PreProd. This action is executed in the step "Confirm successful test". May be the wording is a little bit misleading. It means not an integration/regression test (remember: we have a single change), but just a final decision to approve the import into the Prod system, usually done by the business.

Please see the docu:
https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_Solution_Manager/8b923a2175be4939816f0981b73856c7/d6e6bcc740964311987d440ab83e6684.html

entry.content:
Hello Juwin,

Thank you for the response. However, I couldn't use it. Since, there is a custom existing solution to get the archived file from multiple document types developed in V2 service, organization wishes to reuse it for the ODdata V4 WebAPI development. And the OData V4 solution works fine now. Issue was with the URI. As like V2 service, we can't provide $value at the end of V4 uri. We need to just mention the property name at the end of URI.

https://<your-sap-host>/sap/opu/odata4/<service-namespace>/<service-name>/<version>/<entity-set>(<key>)/<name of the property with document data>

Thank you for the support!

Happy Learning!

Kind regards,

Shahanaz.

entry.title: Re: Equipment transfer from one plant to another plant
entry.content:
You can achieve this requirement in SAP ECC using standard asset transfer and equipment reinstallation processes, combined with proper master data updates and history tracking via equipment and asset reports.

Go to transaction ABUMN (Transfer Within Company Code) to move the asset from one plant to another. Ensure both plants belong to the same company code. Update the cost center, location, and plant fields during the transfer. This will move the asset value and update the asset master record. If the plants are in different company codes, use ABT1N (Intercompany Asset Transfer) instead.

Change the location, plant, and cost center in the equipment master. Link the equipment to the new asset number if needed. This ensures the equipment is correctly tied to the new plant and asset.

If the equipment is also managed as a material, update the plant-specific views in MM02. Ensure the material is extended to the new plant and relevant valuation data is maintained.

SAP tracks equipment usage via

  • Equipment history (IH08): Shows installation, location changes, and maintenance history.
  • Maintenance orders and notifications: Linked to equipment and plant.
  • Asset history sheet (S_ALR_87011990): Shows asset movements and value changes.

To trace usage at the plant level, ensure Equipment is always updated with the correct plant and Maintenance orders are created under the correct plant and equipment.

entry.title: Re: Cross-company contribution margin
entry.content:
See that your S/4HANA system is activated for account-based CO-PA (also called Margin Analysis). It replaces costing-based CO-PA as the default for profitability reporting. It integrates tightly with the Universal Journal (table ACDOCA), making reconciliation with FI and CO much easier. You can still activate costing-based CO-PA if needed, but it‚Äôs no longer the preferred approach.

Set up intercompany billing between Company A and B. Ensure Company A posts COGS and intercompany revenue. Company B posts inventory receipt and customer revenue. Use transfer pricing if needed to reflect internal margins.

Use COPA derivation rules to pull Profit center from material master or sales order. Plant of production from delivery or production order. Ensure these characteristics are included in your operating concern.

entry.title: Re: IAM Apps tab missing in Maintain Business Roles app a...
entry.content:
Good day @beampakorn 

Thank you for your question.

Why do IAM tabs disappear?

This usually means that either the IAM business catalogs or their dependent UI components were not properly activate in your QAS tenant. Their is a dependency on presence of IAM in catalogs & IAM Service Activation in Tenant.

In summary, the Maintain Business Roles app is dynamically displayed based on the availability and activation of the IAM business catalogs and scope item 2XU (Identity and Access Management) in your tenant.

Please note, when you transport a role from your DEV to QAS:

  • If your IAM catalogs are not yet activated in QAS, or
  • If your Identity and Access Management scope is not active,

then the system hides the IAM Apps tab, even though other tabs e.g., Business Catalogs, Restriction, etc appear normally.

Below are steps you can take to solve that issue in the public cloud edition:

  1. In your QAS, open Manage Business Catalogs and activate all SAP_CORE_BC_IAM catalogs.
  2. In CBC, ensure the Identity and Access Management is active.
  3. Ensure you clear Fiori cache and reopen Maintain Business Roles.

Once you have fully activated IAM in QAS, the IAM Apps tab will appear, and you will require no extra authorisation or enhancement.

Have a look at the following references for more details.

Identity and Access Management

Work with IAM Apps of the App Authorization Variant Type

Business Roles, Business Catalogs, App Authorization Variants, Restrictions

Let me know if you have further questions.

 

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: The Future of Planning in Excel: The SAP Analytics Cloud Add-in as a Strategic Frontend ‚Äì Part 2/3
entry.content:
Part 2/3: Data Validation

In the first part of this series, we introduced the SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) add-in for Microsoft Office and positioned it as the strategic successor to Analysis for Office. We covered its modern architecture, seamless integration, and how to build a basic interactive planning sheet.

Now it‚Äôs time to move beyond simple data display and entry. In this second instalment, we‚Äôll dive into one of the most powerful aspects of the add-in: how it works together with native Excel formulas. We‚Äôll show how to use those formulas to create a practical, robust, and essential tool for any planner: a self-service data-validation sheet.

Use case

In most planning processes, a small group of ‚Äúkey users‚Äù monitors and oversees progress. They remind contributors to enter data, catch mistakes early, and help maintain overall planning quality.

In later stages of a planning cycle, it becomes strategically important to know what changed compared to yesterday and why it changed. To streamline this, the SAP Analytics Cloud add-in can be combined with standard Excel techniques to build a lightweight validation hub.

Step 1: Create summary tables for the relevant dimensions

Create one or more SAC-connected tables that summarise your planning data by the dimensions you care about.
Example: in this post we use Country and Material, but in your scenario, it could be Cost Center, Product Group, Customer, etc.

Make sure each table is clearly labelled and, if helpful, filtered to the current planning year for quick scanning.

Step 2: Build a validation sheet with native Excel formulas

On a separate worksheet (‚ÄúValidation‚Äù or similar), use standard Excel functions to pull and compare values from the SAC-connected tables.

This gives you a single list of values drawn from your summary tables, ready for checks and comparisons.

Tips for the validation sheet

  • Lookup & aggregation: Use XLOOKUP, INDEX/MATCH, SUMIFS, or AGGREGATE to retrieve totals for each combination (or whichever grain you need).
  • Change tracking: Add a ‚ÄúYesterday‚Äù (or ‚ÄúBaseline‚Äù) column populated from a prior snapshot (copy-pasted values, a versioned table, or a dated export). Then compute Delta columns.
  • Quality checks: Use simple rules to flag issues like:
    • Missing values where entries are required.
    • Negative or unusually large values.
    • Unexpected zeros for active entities.
  • Conditional formatting: Highlight deltas above a threshold, blanks, or outliers so key users can see problems immediately.
  • Filters & slices: Add filters (e.g., by Region, Planner, Version) to narrow the validation view during review meetings.
  • Notes column: Include a free-text column so reviewers can record the reason for changes (price update, volume re-forecast, currency effect, etc.).

Why this works

  • Self-service: Planners and key users can validate data in Excel without leaving the SAC context.
  • Speed: Native formulas keep it fast and flexible; no macros required.
  • Governance: Clear flags and notes improve auditability and help explain variances.

What‚Äôs next (Part 3)

In the final part of this series, we‚Äôll show you how to transform your Excel sheet into a lightweight automation hub, enabling automatic data entry and streamlined updates to parameter values across your planning solution.

entry.title: Re: Transaction MD74 Fails to Clear VSF Scheduling Data f...
entry.content:
Some of the possible reasons why MD74 didn‚Äôt delete VSF Data are

  • MD74 only deletes PIRs from inactive planning versions. If the VSF data is in version 00 (active), MD74 won‚Äôt remove it. Try with MD62 to manually delete PIRs from active versions.
  • PIRs may be soft pegged to dependent requirements or planned orders. This prevents deletion via MD74. Check for linked elements using MD04 or MD05 for the material and plant.
  • Ensure the key date (21.10.2025) is correctly interpreted by the system. MD74 deletes PIRs up to and including the key date. Confirm that the schedule line 18-102025 falls within this range.

To fix this, perform the below steps

  • Run MD62 for material L003351135NCPAA in plant 5300. Select version 00. Manually delete PIRs for date 18-10-2025.
  • Check MD04 for pegged requirements. If linked to planned orders or reservations, delete those first.
  • Check Strategy Group in material master MRP3 view. Ensure strategy supports PIR deletion (e.g., 10, 40).
  • Use Transaction MD73, analyze PIRs by version and date. Confirm which entries are eligible for deletion.

entry.title: DIY JDBC Sender Adapter for SAP Integration Suite
entry.content:
DIY JDBC Sender Adapter for SAP Integration Suite

Introduction

Are you migrating from SAP PO to Integration Suite and missing the JDBC Sender Adapter for various integration scenarios? If so, I have just the solution for you! In this article I will show you, how to simulate a JDBC Sender Adapter using a smart design approach. My method allows both scheduled and manual triggering (without redeploying your IFlow). I'll guide you step by step through my implementation to enable you to do the same on your use case.

Core Insight

You can simulate a JDBC Sender Adapter by configuring the Request/Reply step and incorporating your needed triggers.

My Step-by-Step Implementation

Entire Integration Process

Part 1: Polling and Decoupling 

  1. Scheduler & Manual Polling

    • I created two entry points for the integration flow:
      • A configurable scheduler for periodic database polls.
      • An HTTP endpoint for manual polling via Postman GET‚Äîperfect for testing or urgent triggers.
  2. Manual and Scheduled Fetch ProcessPolling the Sender DB
  • Used a local subprocess with a Request/Reply step to fetch data from the source database.
  • The fetched data is safely written to a DataStore or a JMS Queue (choose what suits your tenant/scenario) for decoupling and most importantly(at least for me): Retry handling.
SELECT * FROM ${property.JDBC_Schema}.${property.JDBC_Table};

JDBC Poll Process

Part 2: Mapping and Writing to Target DB

Write Data to Target

 

  1. Reading from DataStore/JMS Queue
    • In a second integration process, the data is read from the queue or store.
    • Exchange the sender adapter as needed.
  2. Message Mapping in a Local Subprocess
    • I placed mapping logic inside a local subprocess to isolate errors.
    • If mapping fails, it sets a custom status MappingFailed. 
    • Mapping errors cannot be retried, so the message escalates directly.
      local Mapping Process
  3. Insert into Target DB
    • After a successful mapping, data is inserted into the target database.

Error Handling

  • Errors are sent to a global error handling process, which checks the Nr of retries against the configured max and then yields an end event.
    • Automatic retries is triggered with an Error End.
    • Max retries reached, the message was sent to a Dead Letter Queue (DataStore) and escalates.
      Retry Handling Process
  • Mapping errors escalate instantly. They need to be resolved manually. 

Recommendations for Integration Developers

  • Decouple processes using DataStore or JMS Queue; which makes error handling and retries much easier.
  • Design your flow to be manually triggerable (e.g., via Postman or another IFlow) which comes in handy in an error case or for testing.

Personal Reflection

Honestly, I was surprised at how well this workaround performed, especially with error handling and decoupling. It‚Äôs not as plug-and-play as a native JDBC Sender Adapter in PO. I created a "template" IFlow from this concept, which I can copy everywhere I need. I already migrated multiple scenarios like that and it is almost as plug-and-play as in SAP PO. If you are interested in the template or have any question regarding this topic, contact me!

SAP Integration Suite

entry.title: Obtaining an OAuth Token from SAP XSUAA on SAP BTP Trial ‚Äì A Step-by-Step Guide
entry.content:
Introduction

This guide demonstrates how to obtain an OAuth access token from the SAP XSUAA (XS User Account and Authentication) service in a SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP) trial environment using the client_credentials grant type.

The process covers the creation of the XSUAA service instance, generation of a service key, and retrieval of an access token using curl. This tutorial assumes familiarity with SAP BTP, Cloud Foundry CLI and basic authentication concepts.

1. Define the Security Descriptor

Create a file named xs-security.json with the following content:

{
    "xsappname": "xsuaa-demo",
    "tenant-mode": "dedicated",
    "scopes": [
        {
            "name": "$XSAPPNAME.scope",
            "description": "Default application scope"
        }
    ],
    "role-templates": [
        {
            "name": "Default",
            "description": "Default role",
            "scope-references": [
                "$XSAPPNAME.scope"
            ]
        }
    ]
}

This file defines the application name, scope, and role templates required by the XSUAA service.

2. Create the XSUAA Instance

Using the Cloud Foundry CLI, create the XSUAA service instance:

cf create-service xsuaa application xsuaa-demo -c xs-security.json

Verify that the service has been successfully created:

cf service xsuaa-demo

Ensure the status shows create succeeded before proceeding.

3. Create and Retrieve a Service Key

Next, create a service key to retrieve the credentials required for authentication.

cf create-service-key xsuaa-demo xsuaa-demo-key cf service-key xsuaa-demo xsuaa-demo-key

The output will contain details similar to the following (sensitive values are substituted, <CLIENT_SECRET>, etc):

{
    "credentials": {
        "clientid": "<CLIENT_ID>",
        "clientsecret": "<CLIENT_SECRET>",
        "url": "https://<YOUR_AUTH_DOMAIN>/oauth/token",
        "xsappname": "xsuaa-demo!tXXXXXX"
    }
}

The clientid, clientsecret, and url will be used in the next step to request an access token.

4. Request an Access Token

To obtain an access token, use the client_credentials flow.
Note: If your clientid contains special characters such as ‚Äú!‚Äù, ensure it is wrapped in single quotes to avoid shell expansion.

curl -X POST \
    -u '<CLIENT_ID>:<CLIENT_SECRET>' \
    -d 'grant_type=client_credentials&response_type=token' \
    'https://<YOUR_AUTH_DOMAIN>/oauth/token'

Upon success, the XSUAA service will return a JSON payload similar to the following:

{
    "access_token": "<ACCESS_TOKEN>",
    "token_type": "bearer",
    "expires_in": 43199,
    "scope": "uaa.resource"
}

This token can now be used to authenticate requests to other SAP services or applications secured by XSUAA.

5. Test the Token

To verify that the token is valid, include it in the Authorization header when calling a protected endpoint:

curl -H "Authorization: Bearer <ACCESS_TOKEN>" \ https://<YOUR_APP_DOMAIN>/hello

Expected response:

Hello authenticated user!

6. Common Issues

1. Special characters in client ID or secret
Use single quotes around credentials to prevent shell interpretation errors.

2. Region mismatch
Ensure the domain in your XSUAA credentials matches the region in which your BTP subaccount resides (for example, us10 or eu10).

3. Trial environment delays
In some cases, service provisioning in trial accounts may take longer than expected.

4. Security best practices
Do not expose your client credentials or tokens in source code or public repositories.

Conclusion

This guide outlines the complete process for generating and using an OAuth token from SAP‚Äôs XSUAA service in a BTP trial environment. Following these steps provides a reliable foundation for integrating authentication into SAP-based applications or services.

Keywords: SAP BTP, XSUAA, OAuth2, Cloud Foundry, Authentication, Security, Tutorial

entry.title: Re: SAP Analytics cloud : How Valur Driver Tree Inverse f...
entry.content:
@kiran_s611 

Inverse Formula works in the order its defined. The highest priority is the main the formula and then for inverse it takes the order in which you define them. So in your case the below formula is define for [001] Volume = Price * Quantity

 [002]*[003]|(INVERSE([002]:=[001]/[003]) or (INVERSE([003]:=[001]/[002])))

Volume will be calculated using price and Quantity and if Volume is adjusted then price will be calculated as its defined in that order. Also un booked items are treated as 0 so in this case if volume is un booked and you enter quantity price might not calculate.

Both Quantity and Price cannot be adjusted in proportion of a increase in volume. 10% increase in volume will not be same as increase of 10% price and 10% quantity.

 

Hope this helps !

Nikhil

Nikhil

entry.title: How to avoid double netting of stock between SAP IBP and S/4HANA MRP during planned order creation?
entry.content:
In our SAP IBP Supply Planning process, we are generating planned production orders at the plant level based on net demand (i.e., demand reduced available stock). These planned orders are then transferred to S/4HANA for execution, where MRP is also run.

However, since both IBP and S/4 MRP consider the same available stock, the stock is effectively netted twice ‚Äî once in IBP during planning, and again in S/4 during MRP run. This results in reduced or deleted planned orders after MRP execution.

What is the best practice or recommended system setup to avoid this double netting situation?
Should stock netting be handled only in IBP, or only in S/4, or is there a specific configuration (e.g., MRP type, firming, or planning strategy) to ensure that stock is not deducted twice when IBP planned orders are transferred to S/4HANA?

entry.title: CPI-Quicks #1: How to transform an IFlow Into an API Artifact
entry.content:
Here's a quick tip for anyone who wants to keep their Integration Suite "semantically clean": How to transform an IFlow into an API artifact.

The Short Version

When using a HTTP sender adapter, logically you should also use an API artifact, because the adapter exposes an endpoint like an API. But I don't always think about that, when I start out designing a process. In the past, I had to re-implement a whole new API artifact, copying and pasting all flow steps and messing up configurations on the way. Until I found out that you can turn an Integration Flow into a REST or SOAP API artifact by changing just one line in its manifest file. 

How-to (Step-by-Step)

  1. Spot the Difference

    • Under the hood, API Artifacts and Integration Flows are almost the same. The only real difference is the value of SAP-BundleType in the MANIFEST.MF file.
    • That tiny detail is what lets you make the switch.

  1. Download Your Integration Flow

    • Grab your IFlow artifact from SAP Integration Suite.

  2. Unzip and Look Inside

    • Open the zip file and go to /META-INF/MANIFEST.MF.

  3. Change the Manifest

    • Find the line that says:

      SAP-BundleType: IntegrationFlow

    • Change it to either:

      SAP-BundleType: SOAPAPIProvider

      or

      SAP-BundleType: RESTAPIProvider

      depending on what you need.

  4. Zip It Back Up

    • Save your changes, then re-zip the whole artifact folder.
      zip IFlow source

  5. Upload as an API Artifact

    • In SAP Integration Suite, start a new API Artifact, choose ‚ÄúUpload,‚Äù and pick your updated zip file.
    • Give it a name, hit ‚ÄúCreate‚Äù and ‚ÄúDeploy.‚Äù
      Create API Artifact

  6. Done!

    • You‚Äôve just turned your Integration Flow into a REST or SOAP API Artifact‚Äîwithout repeating all your work.

      two IFlows converted into two APIs

Caution!

  • Be Careful: Editing manifest files directly can be risky. Double-check everything before you deploy.
  • Always keep a copy of your IFlow at hand, so you are save when you mess something up.

Thank you for reading and may this trick save you some hours!

SAP Integration Suite API

entry.title: Re: Output message triggered even Output ignored (require...
entry.content:
Since 902 is a custom routine and added logic specific to the Business, it is not sure, how this can happen. However, please note, output type ZEOR might be reprocessed manually via VL71 or automatically via a background job. These jobs do not re-evaluate the routine, they simply process existing output records.

Check if ZEOR is set to trigger automatically in condition records (NACE ‚Üí V2 ‚Üí Output Types). If so, it may be added to the delivery regardless of the routine result, and then processed unless explicitly suppressed.

If ZEOR is linked to a specific partner function (e.g., SH or SP), and that partner is present, the output may trigger independently of the routine logic.

So go to VL03N ‚Üí Extras ‚Üí Output ‚Üí Header. Check if ZEOR was added manually or via default condition record.

Review SM37 for jobs running RSNAST00 or similar. These jobs process existing outputs and do not re-evaluate the routine.

Add a breakpoint in routine 902 and simulate delivery creation to confirm it‚Äôs being called and SY-SUBRC is set correctly.

entry.title: Re: ChaRM 4 system landscape not importing to Pre-Prod
entry.content:
I would like to add just that preliminary import is not something that happens in every Normal Change. You have to go through status "request preliminary import", because this way there is a preliminary import flag added to the Normal Change, and the status changes trigger the imports. Whereas, if you don't do the request preliminary import step, some of the same statuses are used by the classic Normal Change process (Imported in production, for example), but don't trigger imports at the status change.

Also, in the help page for preliminary import , it explicitly states that the status "tested for production import" lines up with the transport request being put in the production system import queue. My recommendation is that, if the names of statuses seem confusing, there is the possibility of customizing the names of statuses, import actions in each status, etc.

entry.title: Re: Fiori Launchpad for Sourcing and Procurement
entry.content:
Hi @JackN11 

In public cloud edition, the Supplier Down Payments process is delivered through the 18B scope item. You can enable it by:

  1. Go to your Central Business Configuration (CBC), --> then activate scope item 18B (Supplier Down Payments) under Finance --> Accounts Payable.
  2. Deploy the configuration so the related SSCUIs and business roles are available.
  3. Then, in SSCUI (Define Terms of Payment), create or edit a payment term and set the Down Payment Indicator to X.
  4. Assign this term to your PO or supplier.

After activation, you can use:

  • Display Supplier Down Payment Requests
  • Manage Supplier Line Items
  • Monitor Purchase Order Items
  • Display Supplier Balances

to track and manage down payments across procurement and finance.

If 18B doesn‚Äôt appear in CBC, ensure to verify your country localisation and scope phase, or open an incident.

Have a look at the following references for more details.

Manage Supplier Down Payment Requests

Approval Workflows for Supplier Down Payment Requests

Let me know if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: About scope items for material closing period(MMPV)
entry.content:
Hello @ki2003 ,

As @FernandaKlauck explained in his post,

The Material Closing Period (MMPV) function was never moved to 3F0; it remains accessible via the Close Periods (F2540) app under Master Data ‚Äì Administration. The 3F0 scope covers event-based costing, with material period close continuing separately.

This page describes how users open or close posting periods for logistics areas like Materials Management. This functionality, formerly managed through transaction MMPV, is now integrated into the SAP Fiori app instead of the 3F0 (Event-Based Costing) scope. SAP Help-General Ledger Accounting-Opening and Closing Posting Periods

BEI ‚Üí 3F0: BEI Period-End Closing ‚Äì Plant deprecated as of 2408, decommissioned in 2602; costing moves to 3F0 Event-Based Production Cost Posting KBA -3599914 - About the transition from the scope item BEI to the scope item 3F0

Why 3F0 test scripts don‚Äôt show MMPV: 3F0 handles event-based production cost posting. The material posting period closes the classic ‚ÄúMMPV‚Äù function, which is separate from logistics control. SAP Help Portal-Product Accounting-Event-Based (3F0) versus Period-Based (BEI) in Production Costs of Manufacturing Orders

MMPV's current location: Use the Close Periods feature in S/4HANA Cloud (Fiori) via Master Data ‚Üí Administration to open or close MM posting periods. SAP‚Äôs help documentation and SAP blog provide the title and navigation path.  SAP Help Portal-Create New Open MM Posting Period - MDS (BNZ)-Closing MM Period and Opening New Posting Period

Authorisations to run Close Periods: If users cannot see or run it, check authorisations. KBA 2748224 documents the Close Periods app error ‚ÄúNo authorization to carry out period closing‚Äù and mentions the relevant business roles/catalogues.

In brief

  • MMPV wasn‚Äôt moved into 3F0, so you won‚Äôt find it in 3F0 test scripts.
  • Continue to close MM periods via Close Periods (Fiori) under Master Data ‚Üí Administration; ensure proper authorisation as per KBA 2748224.
  • The BEI ‚Üí 3F0 change affects production costing, not the existence of the Close Periods activity.

Let me know if you need further support

With kind regards

Chuma
